body:
@prameshgautam 

I'm not sure I understand your question -- VoxelMorph itself is a method to output the deformation field for two images (an unsupervised neural network). Did you have a more specific question about part of the method?

@adalca Thank you for the response. I think I was not clear in my question. I wanted to know the method used for image transformation and looks like Stationary velocity field is used for diffeomorphic transformation. Please correct me if I am wrong.

Also, I have a situation where the inverse transformation needs to be computed. Is this already available in voxelmorph? I am trying to use the PyTorch version.

Voxelmorph is a general purpose framework for learning to output deformations from data. This idea can be used with a varity of transformation types. Our library supposets a few, including standard deformation fields and diffeomorhisms through velocity fields. 

If you need inverses, you should definitely use diffeomorphisms. The pytorch implementation includes a `neg_flow` variable that maintains the inverse deformation field: https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/blob/6a9522810455e8e6333beebf133398e2f1a2fbc8/voxelmorph/torch/networks.py#L199

Thank you :). I have one more question regarding running the training script. The atlas.npz file contains only **vol** and **seg** parameters. **vol** seems to refer to moving image and **seg** to auxiliary information in case of semi-supervised learning. I couldn't figure out how the fixed image is passed during training.

Right, at the moment npz is just the default format in the example `train.py` scripts, but the internal I/O utils also support npy, nifti, and mgh/mgz files. The loader assumes by default that the npz image data is stored under the 'vol' key, and the example training script just searches for any npz files in the `datadir` path provided on the command line. So, you could always customize your list of training files by modifying:

https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/blob/6a9522810455e8e6333beebf133398e2f1a2fbc8/scripts/torch/train.py#L61

@ahoopes my question was regarding the fixed image rather than the image format. Since **vol** refers to moving image and **seg** refers to information for semi-supervised learning, how is the moving image passed to training?

if you're registering scan to atlas, then our `train.py` sets the atlas as the fixed image and the scans in the `datadir` are treated as the moving images.

If your files are npz files with the volume stored in the `vol` variable, these will be read by the generator and passed to the model as moving images.

I'm not sure I understand your question beyond this?

@adalca my use case is of scan to scan registration and I would like to pass two volumes(moving and fixed) to the network. I am able to figure out the moving image for scan to scan registration. My question is how to pass the scan for the fixed image. I can change the code of reading the image to read the moving and fixed image to pass to the network. But I wanted to understand the existing code for efficiency as it seems efficient than the loader I'm trying to implement. I hope I am able to clarify my question. Thank you for your help.
our code defaults to scan-to-scan if you don't supply an atlas. https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/blob/master/scripts/tf/train.py#L65

The current setup will randomly grab images from the folder as fixed and moving at each iteration. If you'd like to be more specific than that, I think you need to modify the generators. @ahoopes can verify.

Yes, the default generators are configured to pick, at each training step, two random files (representing moving and fixed images) from the training files available in the datadir, so if there's only one file, the model will just be learning to register the same image to itself over and over again. If you want to get specific about what exactly will be used as moving and fixed images at each training iteration, you'll have to write your own data generator.
